content:
The 7-minute workout is an excellent choice for a morning exercise routine.

As for when to do it, it ultimately depends on your personal preferences and body. Here are some pros and cons of doing the 7-minute workout right after waking up versus after having coffee and breakfast:

**Doing the 7-minute workout right after waking up:**

Pros:

1. **Improved mental clarity:** Exercise has been shown to increase alertness and boost cognitive function. Doing the workout first thing in the morning can help you feel more alert and focused.
2. **Increased motivation:** Getting your exercise out of the way early can give you a sense of accomplishment and motivation to tackle the rest of your day.
3. **Less likely to be interrupted:** You're less likely to be interrupted or distracted by other activities or tasks when you do your workout first thing in the morning.

Cons:

1. **Stiffness and flexibility:** Your muscles may be stiffer and less flexible in the morning, which could affect your performance and increase the risk of injury.
2. **Low energy:** You might not have the same energy levels as you would after having a cup of coffee or eating breakfast, which could impact the intensity of your workout.

**Doing the 7-minute workout after having coffee and breakfast:**

Pros:

1. **Increased energy:** Caffeine and a nutritious breakfast can give you a energy boost, allowing you to perform your workout with more intensity and enthusiasm.
2. **Better flexibility and mobility:** Your muscles will be warmer and more flexible after eating and moving around, which can help you perform exercises with better form and range of motion.
3. **Better digestion:** Exercising on a full stomach can help improve digestion and reduce the risk of discomfort or cramps during the workout.

Cons:

1. **Less mental clarity:** You might feel more sluggish or lethargic after eating a meal, which could affect your mental focus and motivation.
2. **More likely to be interrupted:** You're more likely to be interrupted or distracted by other activities or tasks after eating breakfast, which could make it harder to fit in your workout.

Ultimately, it's up to you to decide what works best for your body and schedule. If you're not a morning person, you might prefer to do your workout after having coffee and breakfast. However, if you're someone who feels more alert and energized in the morning, doing the workout right after waking up could be a great way to start your day.

Remember to listen to your body and adjust your approach as needed. You can always experiment with both options and see what works best for you.
